summary_sections.content: Personal care product chemicals include plasticizers, solvents, fragrance fixatives, preservatives and packaging materials used in cosmetics, lotions, shampoos and other consumer goods. These substances are found in domestic environments and are catalogued in regulatory and scientific toxicology references.

Exposure occurs primarily through direct application of products, inhalation of volatile constituents from aerosols or sprays, ingestion of residues via lip or oral-care products, and transfer from packaging materials into food or skin contact items.
bullets: Dermal absorption from lotions, creams and cosmetics
Oral exposure through lip or mouth-applied products or inadvertent ingestion
Migration from packaging materials or plasticizers into skin, food or liquids

summary_sections.content: Studies in peer-reviewed literature show that certain chemicals used in personal care products can act as endocrine-active agents, with potential impacts on reproductive and developmental systems, metabolic or hormonal regulation. Measured levels in the general population are typically lower than doses that cause clear adverse outcomes, but low-dose and cumulative exposure effects are under active investigation.

In the United States the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) monitors cosmetic-ingredient safety under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act). Plasticizers and other additives are subject to specific regulatory rules and monitoring programs track human biomonitoring data for exposure to key compounds.
